1201: Ah, the forest hides many secretsâ€¦ and I? Iâ€™ve stolen a few. These Gemsâ€”theyâ€™re not mine, but Titania has more than she needs. Youâ€™ve something I crave: Olive Bread, warm and rich. Trade with me, and I might whisper tales of glowing eyes in the dark, wings that shimmer at moonrise, and dragons that speak in riddles. Keep an ear open, and a dagger close.
1202: My bounty is as boundless as the sea, my love as deepâ€”but he is gone, and all that remains is a portrait and pain. Angelo took both. Bring me Romeoâ€™s likeness, torn from my chamber, and Iâ€™ll give you Tulips red as the blood spilt on Veronaâ€™s stones. Let this be our new balcony: you below, bearing justice.
1203: Give me life, give me love, but most of allâ€”give me Port! In exchange, a sprig of Feverfew, dearer than gold to some, especially that wide-eyed Helena. Says sheâ€™s after crowns and legends, poor girl. Me? Iâ€™m after a full belly and a gentle nap. â€˜Thou art so fat-witted with drinking of old sack,â€™ they once told me. Ha! They were not wrong.
1204: Hereâ€™s rosemary, for remembranceâ€”and nightshade, for regrets. My potions are not for the faint of will. With the right leaf, I can mend your limbs or muddle your tongue. â€˜I do remember an apothecary,â€™ said a boy once, and he paid the price. But you? You look wiser. Bring me rare roots and bitter seeds, and Iâ€™ll mix you something worth the danger.
1205: Something is rotten, still. I feel it in the soil. I once ruled, loved, lost. Helena burned through me like summer lightning. And Leontes? He could not forgive the thaw. â€˜The lady doth protest too much,â€™ they saidâ€”let them. If you see Helena, tell her the roses know her name. If you see Leontes, tell him I have not forgotten the winter.
1206: My grief is a statueâ€”silent, but never still. I buried my crown in snow the day Gertrude chose her garden over me. â€˜Exit, pursued by a bearâ€™? No, I fled myself. Now I wait, among stone and silence. Bring me what was once mineâ€”the Kingâ€™s Crownâ€”and Iâ€™ll pay in Gold, more than the weight of memory. But beware: some thrones carry curses.
1207: This bridge is mine, by Sycorax my mother.â€™ Prospero tried to steal it with spells and smiles. They called me beast, but I am of earth and storm, born to wild truth. I trade bones for Silver, tokens of the dead for coin of the living. Touch nothing lightly in these woods. Bring me what others fear, and I shall make you richâ€”or haunted.
